_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Coastal Pacific Food Distributors uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration of goods for distribution.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or federal RMP requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reduc                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                notification of the local emergency responders.  This EAP also includes a specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR ? 1910.38(a).

This facility has also

coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.
 
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

 The Coastal Pacific Food Distributors facility is located at 1015 Performance Drive in Stockton, California between Sperry Road and Aviation Drive.  The facility lies approximately 1.4 miles east of Interstate Highway 5 in an area comprised primarily of agricultural and industrial facilities.  The small town of French Camp is located about 1 mile southwest of the facility.  The Stockton Metropolitan Airport lies approximately ½ mile east of the plant.  State Highway 99 runs east-west and the closest point to the plant is about 2.5 miles to the east.  The facility also lies very close to the Union Pacific railroad tracks.

Coastal Pacific (CPF) was founded in 1986 as a military distributor in support of the overseas bases located in Japan, Korea, Okinawa, and Guam.  In less than a decade, CPF became the premier military distributor for the entire West Coast and the Far East.  With full-service distribution centers in Stockton, California; Ontario, California; and Fife, Washington, Coastal Pacific is positioned to provide expedient service to all bases.  CPF provides state-of-the-art information systems designed for timely sales and shipping information with a sole focus on the military resale industry.

This facility stores and distributes various food and non-food related supplies under approximately 500,000 square feet of warehouse space, a portion of which is refrigerated.

Regulated Substance Handled

The Coastal Pacific Food Distributors facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a

actors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.

The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This process is a new installation and, therefore, has no history at this time.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills twice per year.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required prior to initial startup of the system.  The PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations were implemented, deemed unnecessary since no improvements to safety would result, or planned for implementation at a later date.  Upcoming events include:

? Training of employees to conduct daily monitoring of system conditions
? Consideration of provision of backup power for the public address system
? Minor hardware changes to enhance accessibility
